posts.content:
"🚨 Critical Vulnerabilities Alert in ConnectWise Software 🚨"

Two vulnerabilities have been identified in ConnectWise's remote desktop software, ScreenConnect, affecting versions 23.9.7 and prior. The first vulnerability (CVE-2024-1708) is a path-traversal issue allowing potential remote code execution or access to sensitive data, rated with a high severity score of 8.4.

The second (CVE-2024-1709) is an authentication bypass, considered critical with a severity score of 10.0, and is easily exploitable with existing proof-of-concept exploits. ConnectWise has issued updates for cloud-hosted instances, but self-hosted deployments need immediate patching. The exposure is global, with significant concentrations in the United States, and it's expected that cybercriminals and nation-state actors will actively exploit these vulnerabilities.

| ---- | ---- | ---- |
| CVE Number | Description | *CVSS Severity* |
| CVE-2024-1708 | ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by a path-traversal vulnerability, which may allow an attacker the ability to execute remote code or directly impact confidential data or critical systems. | 8.4 High |
| CVE-2024-1709 | ConnectWise ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by an authentication bypass using an alternate path or channel vulnerability, which may allow an attacker direct access to confidential information or critical systems. | 10.0 Critical |

Professionals using ConnectWise must urgently patch their systems to mitigate these vulnerabilities. The discovery underscores the importance of rigorous security practices in protecting IT infrastructures.

🛡️💻🔐

Tags: #CyberSecurity #VulnerabilityAlert #ConnectWise #CVE2024_1708 #CVE2024_1709 #PatchManagement #ITSecurity #RemoteCodeExecution #PrivilegeEscalation

Source: Unit42 by Palo Alto Networks

Mandiant updated their remediation and hardening guide for responding to the ConnectWise ScreenConnect vunerabilities CVE-2024-1709 and CVE-2024-1708. posts.content:
Huntress covers mass exploitation of ScreenConnect vulnerabilities CVE-2024-1709 (and CVE-2024-1708? maybe) in the wild. This includes everything from additional payloads, additional remote monitoring and management (RMM) tools, to cryptominers and Lockbit (variant) ransomware. IOC provided.
🔗 https://www.huntress.com/blog/slashandgrab-screen-connect-post-exploitation-in-the-wild-cve-2024-1709-cve-2024-1708

account.note: Current open-source cyber threat intelligence, critical vulnerabilities, zero-days, proofs of concept, cybercrime/cyberespionage, threat actors/APTs, IOCs, and other cybersecurity and intelligence news.

posts.content:
Sophos covers attacks involving the new ConnectWise ScreenConnect vulnerabilities. This includes a Lockbit ransomware variant (buhtiRansom) using the leaked builder tool in 2023. Other attacks involved dropping AsyncRAT, Rust infostealer, and Vidar/Redline stealer. One attack dropped another remote access client called SimpleHelp, followed up by CRYPT ransomware. There were also Cobalt Strike and Xworm payloads. Sophos provides threat hunting information. No IOC.
🔗 https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2024/02/23/connectwise-screenconnect-attacks-deliver-malware/

posts.content:
Sophos covers attacks involving the new ConnectWise ScreenConnect vulnerabilities. This includes a Lockbit ransomware variant (buhtiRansom) using the leaked builder tool in 2023. Other attacks involved dropping AsyncRAT, Rust infostealer, and Vidar/Redline stealer. One attack dropped another remote access client called SimpleHelp, followed up by CRYPT ransomware. There were also Cobalt Strike and Xworm payloads. Sophos provides threat hunting information. No IOC.

posts.content:
@campuscodi one question I have is, do they even need to exploit CVE-2024-1708? With CVE-2024-1709, they create an admin user on the ScreenConnect server, giving them full control. This is a one character cheat, whereas 1708 requires user interaction and privileges (CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:R/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H)

I don't specifically see it in the Trend Micro article, but is there actual evidence of CVE-2024-1708 exploitation? Since unpatched versions of ScreenConnect are vulnerable to both 1708 and 1709, it's almost certainly going to make 1709 the more valuable exploit.

posts.content:
"🚨 Critical Vulnerabilities Alert in ConnectWise Software 🚨"

Two vulnerabilities have been identified in ConnectWise's remote desktop software, ScreenConnect, affecting versions 23.9.7 and prior. The first vulnerability (CVE-2024-1708) is a path-traversal issue allowing potential remote code execution or access to sensitive data, rated with a high severity score of 8.4.

The second (CVE-2024-1709) is an authentication bypass, considered critical with a severity score of 10.0, and is easily exploitable with existing proof-of-concept exploits. ConnectWise has issued updates for cloud-hosted instances, but self-hosted deployments need immediate patching. The exposure is global, with significant concentrations in the United States, and it's expected that cybercriminals and nation-state actors will actively exploit these vulnerabilities.

| ---- | ---- | ---- |
| CVE Number | Description | *CVSS Severity* |
| CVE-2024-1708 | ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by a path-traversal vulnerability, which may allow an attacker the ability to execute remote code or directly impact confidential data or critical systems. | 8.4 High |
| CVE-2024-1709 | ConnectWise ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by an authentication bypass using an alternate path or channel vulnerability, which may allow an attacker direct access to confidential information or critical systems. | 10.0 Critical |

Professionals using ConnectWise must urgently patch their systems to mitigate these vulnerabilities. The discovery underscores the importance of rigorous security practices in protecting IT infrastructures.

🛡️💻🔐

Tags: #CyberSecurity #VulnerabilityAlert #ConnectWise #CVE2024_1708 #CVE2024_1709 #PatchManagement #ITSecurity #RemoteCodeExecution #PrivilegeEscalation

Source: Unit42 by Palo Alto Networks

posts.content:
"🚨 Critical Vulnerabilities Alert in ConnectWise Software 🚨"

Two vulnerabilities have been identified in ConnectWise's remote desktop software, ScreenConnect, affecting versions 23.9.7 and prior. The first vulnerability (CVE-2024-1708) is a path-traversal issue allowing potential remote code execution or access to sensitive data, rated with a high severity score of 8.4.

The second (CVE-2024-1709) is an authentication bypass, considered critical with a severity score of 10.0, and is easily exploitable with existing proof-of-concept exploits. ConnectWise has issued updates for cloud-hosted instances, but self-hosted deployments need immediate patching. The exposure is global, with significant concentrations in the United States, and it's expected that cybercriminals and nation-state actors will actively exploit these vulnerabilities.

| ---- | ---- | ---- |
| CVE Number | Description | *CVSS Severity* |
| CVE-2024-1708 | ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by a path-traversal vulnerability, which may allow an attacker the ability to execute remote code or directly impact confidential data or critical systems. | 8.4 High |
| CVE-2024-1709 | ConnectWise ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by an authentication bypass using an alternate path or channel vulnerability, which may allow an attacker direct access to confidential information or critical systems. | 10.0 Critical |

Professionals using ConnectWise must urgently patch their systems to mitigate these vulnerabilities. The discovery underscores the importance of rigorous security practices in protecting IT infrastructures.

🛡️💻🔐

Tags: #CyberSecurity #VulnerabilityAlert #ConnectWise #CVE2024_1708 #CVE2024_1709 #PatchManagement #ITSecurity #RemoteCodeExecution #PrivilegeEscalation

Source: Unit42 by Palo Alto Networks

posts.content:
Huntress covers mass exploitation of ScreenConnect vulnerabilities CVE-2024-1709 (and CVE-2024-1708? maybe) in the wild. This includes everything from additional payloads, additional remote monitoring and management (RMM) tools, to cryptominers and Lockbit (variant) ransomware. IOC provided.
🔗 https://www.huntress.com/blog/slashandgrab-screen-connect-post-exploitation-in-the-wild-cve-2024-1709-cve-2024-1708

#ConnectWise #ScreenConnect #CVE_2024_1709 #CVE_2024_1708 #threatintel #buhtiRansom #Lockbit #ransomware #AsyncRAT #infostealer #Vidar #Redline #CobaltStrike #Xworm #SimpleHelp #cryptransomware #cybercrime

account.note: Current open-source cyber threat intelligence, critical vulnerabilities, zero-days, proofs of concept, cybercrime/cyberespionage, threat actors/APTs, IOCs, and other cybersecurity and intelligence news.

posts.content:
Sophos covers attacks involving the new ConnectWise ScreenConnect vulnerabilities. This includes a Lockbit ransomware variant (buhtiRansom) using the leaked builder tool in 2023. Other attacks involved dropping AsyncRAT, Rust infostealer, and Vidar/Redline stealer. One attack dropped another remote access client called SimpleHelp, followed up by CRYPT ransomware. There were also Cobalt Strike and Xworm payloads. Sophos provides threat hunting information. No IOC.
🔗 https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2024/02/23/connectwise-screenconnect-attacks-deliver-malware/

#ConnectWise #ScreenConnect #CVE_2024_1709 #CVE_2024_1708 #threatintel #buhtiRansom #Lockbit #ransomware #AsyncRAT #infostealer #Vidar #Redline #CobaltStrike #Xworm #SimpleHelp #cryptransomware #cybercrime

Two vulnerabilities have been identified in ConnectWise's remote desktop software, ScreenConnect, affecting versions 23.9.7 and prior. The first vulnerability (CVE-2024-1708) is a path-traversal issue allowing potential remote code execution or access to sensitive data, rated with a high severity score of 8.4.

The second (CVE-2024-1709) is an authentication bypass, considered critical with a severity score of 10.0, and is easily exploitable with existing proof-of-concept exploits. ConnectWise has issued updates for cloud-hosted instances, but self-hosted deployments need immediate patching. The exposure is global, with significant concentrations in the United States, and it's expected that cybercriminals and nation-state actors will actively exploit these vulnerabilities.

| ---- | ---- | ---- |
| CVE Number | Description | *CVSS Severity* |
| CVE-2024-1708 | ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by a path-traversal vulnerability, which may allow an attacker the ability to execute remote code or directly impact confidential data or critical systems. | 8.4 High |
| CVE-2024-1709 | ConnectWise ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by an authentication bypass using an alternate path or channel vulnerability, which may allow an attacker direct access to confidential information or critical systems. | 10.0 Critical |

Professionals using ConnectWise must urgently patch their systems to mitigate these vulnerabilities. The discovery underscores the importance of rigorous security practices in protecting IT infrastructures.

posts.content:
Mandiant updated their remediation and hardening guide for responding to the ConnectWise ScreenConnect vunerabilities CVE-2024-1709 and CVE-2024-1708. This 19 page report contains proactive preparation and hardening actions, containment and initial investigative steps, remediation steps, and additional hardening measures.

posts.content:
Huntress covers mass exploitation of ScreenConnect vulnerabilities CVE-2024-1709 (and CVE-2024-1708? maybe) in the wild. This includes everything from additional payloads, additional remote monitoring and management (RMM) tools, to cryptominers and Lockbit (variant) ransomware. IOC provided.
🔗 https://www.huntress.com/blog/slashandgrab-screen-connect-post-exploitation-in-the-wild-cve-2024-1709-cve-2024-1708

#ConnectWise #ScreenConnect #CVE_2024_1709 #CVE_2024_1708 #threatintel #buhtiRansom #Lockbit #ransomware #AsyncRAT #infostealer #Vidar #Redline #CobaltStrike #Xworm #SimpleHelp #cryptransomware #cybercrime

account.note: Current open-source cyber threat intelligence, critical vulnerabilities, zero-days, proofs of concept, cybercrime/cyberespionage, threat actors/APTs, IOCs, and other cybersecurity and intelligence news.

posts.content:
Sophos covers attacks involving the new ConnectWise ScreenConnect vulnerabilities. This includes a Lockbit ransomware variant (buhtiRansom) using the leaked builder tool in 2023. Other attacks involved dropping AsyncRAT, Rust infostealer, and Vidar/Redline stealer. One attack dropped another remote access client called SimpleHelp, followed up by CRYPT ransomware. There were also Cobalt Strike and Xworm payloads. Sophos provides threat hunting information. No IOC.
🔗 https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2024/02/23/connectwise-screenconnect-attacks-deliver-malware/

#ConnectWise #ScreenConnect #CVE_2024_1709 #CVE_2024_1708 #threatintel #buhtiRansom #Lockbit #ransomware #AsyncRAT #infostealer #Vidar #Redline #CobaltStrike #Xworm #SimpleHelp #cryptransomware #cybercrime

posts.content:
Unit 42 posts a late night warning about ConnectWise ScreenConnect Vulnerabilities CVE-2024-1708 and CVE-2024-1709. Waiting out the commotion of the past 12 hours certainly helped. They cover the main talking points of these vulnerabilities' severity, being trivially exploitable, the existence of proofs of concept, active exploitation, and indicators of compromise. Oh and they include CVE IDs, which many publications today did not update their articles with.

posts.content:
@austinlarsen @simontsui nbd, you're not the only one.

I'm still on the (now somewhat passive) hunt for any real evidence of exploitation for the other one. Lots of conjecture, loads of hits for CVE-2024-1709, but nothing solid for CVE-2024-1708. Every news outlet seems to just conflate the two and sometimes gets them backwards.

account.note: Current open-source cyber threat intelligence, critical vulnerabilities, zero-days, proofs of concept, cybercrime/cyberespionage, threat actors/APTs, IOCs, and other cybersecurity and intelligence news.

posts.content:
@campuscodi one question I have is, do they even need to exploit CVE-2024-1708? With CVE-2024-1709, they create an admin user on the ScreenConnect server, giving them full control. This is a one character cheat, whereas 1708 requires user interaction and privileges (CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:R/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H)

I don't specifically see it in the Trend Micro article, but is there actual evidence of CVE-2024-1708 exploitation? Since unpatched versions of ScreenConnect are vulnerable to both 1708 and 1709, it's almost certainly going to make 1709 the more valuable exploit.

posts.content:
@todb ConnectWise's security advisory lacks definitive verbiage that shows which vulnerability was exploited. Based on their language, and with no clear delineation, I was led to believe that both vulnerabilities were exploited.

However, given how trivial CVE-2024-1709 is /, there'd be no point in exploiting 1708.

posts.content:
@rallias @mttaggart likely referring to ConnectWise ScreenConnect remote code execution vulnerabilities. They were disclosed without CVE IDs on 19 February 2024.

According to CVE.org records, Cybersecurity And Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) U.S. Civilian Government assigned CVE-2024-1708 (8.4 high) to the path traversal vulnerability and CVE-2024-1709 (10.0 critical) to the authentication bypass vulnerability.

  • Security advisory: https://www.connectwise.com/company/trust/security-bulletins/connectwise-screenconnect-23.9.8
  • CVE.org https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-1708
  • CVE.org https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-1709
  • Technical analyses: https://www.huntress.com/blog/a-catastrophe-for-control-understanding-the-screenconnect-authentication-bypass
  • Proof of Concept: https://github.com/watchtowrlabs/connectwise-screenconnect_auth-bypass-add-user-poc
  • Proof of Concept 2: https://www.horizon3.ai/attack-research/red-team/connectwise-screenconnect-auth-bypass-deep-dive/

posts.content:
@GossiTheDog Don't quote me on this but a CVE Numbering Authority is working with ConnectWise to assign CVE IDs. (EDIT: CISA assigned CVE-2024-1709 and CVE-2024-1708 to the actively exploited ConnectWise ScreenConnect RCE vulnerabilities)
CISA will likely add it to the KEV Catalog soon after those CVE IDs are published. (EDIT: CISA added CVE-2024-1709 to the KEV today 22 February 2024)

Horizon3 also provided a Proof of Concept in case you wanted a second opinion: https://www.horizon3.ai/attack-research/red-team/connectwise-screenconnect-auth-bypass-deep-dive/

posts.content: Zyxel Patches Remote Code Execution Bug in Firewall Products https://www.securityweek.com/zyxel-patches-remote-code-execution-bug-in-firewall-products/ #NetworkSecurity #Vulnerabilities #CVE20236397 #CVE20236398 #CVE20236399 #CVE20236764 #Zyxel

CVE-2023-6398.description:
A post-authentication command injection vulnerability in the file upload binary in Zyxel ATP series firmware versions from 4.32 through 5.37 Patch 1, USG FLEX series firmware versions from 4.50 through 5.37 Patch 1, USG FLEX 50(W) series firmware versions from 4.16 through 5.37 Patch 1, USG20(W)-VPN series firmware versions from 4.16 through 5.37 Patch 1, 

USG FLEX H series firmware versions from 1.10 through 1.10 Patch 1,

NWA50AX firmware versions through 6.29(ABYW.3), WAC500 firmware versions through 6.65(ABVS.1), WAX300H firmware versions through 6.60(ACHF.1), and WBE660S firmware versions through 6.65(ACGG.1) could allow an authenticated attacker with administrator privileges to execute some operating system (OS) commands on an affected device via FTP.

CVE-2023-6399.description: A format string vulnerability in Zyxel ATP series firmware versions from 4.32 through 5.37 Patch 1, USG FLEX series firmware versions from 4.50 through 5.37 Patch 1, USG FLEX 50(W) series firmware versions from 4.16 through 5.37 Patch 1, USG20(W)-VPN series firmware versions from 4.16 through 5.37 Patch 1, and USG FLEX H series firmware versions from 1.10 through 1.10 Patch 1 could allow an authenticated IPSec VPN user to cause DoS conditions against the “deviceid” daemon by sending a crafted hostname to an affected device if it has the “Device Insight” feature enabled.

CVE-2023-6764.description: A format string vulnerability in a function of the IPSec VPN feature in Zyxel ATP series firmware versions from 4.32 through 5.37 Patch 1, USG FLEX series firmware versions from 4.50 through 5.37 Patch 1, USG FLEX 50(W) series firmware versions from 4.16 through 5.37 Patch 1, and USG20(W)-VPN series firmware versions from 4.16 through 5.37 Patch 1 could allow an attacker to achieve unauthorized remote code execution by sending a sequence of specially crafted payloads containing an invalid pointer; however, such an attack would require detailed knowledge of an affected device’s memory layout and configuration.

posts.content:
VMware security advisory: CVE-2024-22251 (5.9 medium) VMware Workstation and Fusion contain an out-of-bounds read vulnerability in the USB CCID (chip card interface device). A malicious actor with local administrative privileges on a virtual machine may trigger an out-of-bounds read leading to information disclosure. Fixed in Workstation 17.5.1 and Fusion 13.5.1. No mention of exploitation.
🔗 https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2024-0005.html

#VMware #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_22251 #informationdisclosure

posts.content: The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2024-23204 (CVSS score: 7.5), was addressed by Apple on January 22, 2024, with the release of iOS 17.3, iPadOS 17.3, macOS Sonoma 14.3, and watchOS 10.3. https://thehackernews.com/2024/02/researchers-detail-apples-recent-zero.html

CVE-2024-23204.description: The issue was addressed with additional permissions checks. This issue is fixed in macOS Sonoma 14.3, watchOS 10.3, iOS 17.3 and iPadOS 17.3. A shortcut may be able to use sensitive data with certain actions without prompting the user.

posts.content:
watchTowr picks apart IBM’s “Operational Decision Manager” (ODM), walking through how they uncovered CVE-2024-22320 (9.8 critical deserialization of untrusted data) and CVE-2024-22319 (8.1 high? JNDI injection to RCE) . It's worth noting that NVD assigned different scores that align with the impact. Humorous article that is Street Fighter-themed.
🔗 https://labs.watchtowr.com/double-k-o-rce-in-ibm-operation-decision-manager/

@wdormann and @reverseics would like this:

Fantastic, we’re making good progress with some opportunistic button-bashing (adding a '/' there, a ';' there, and see what we get :) ).

#IBM #ODM #vulnerability #CVE_2024_22320 #CVE_2024_22319 #watchTowr

posts.content:
Ivanti has a frequently asked questions (FAQ) blog post from 14 February 2024 addressing questions about their Ivanti Connect Secure, Policy Secure and ZTA gateway products. Important to note that "As of 14 February, Ivanti has a build available for all supported versions." It also responds to Eclypsium's claim of old open source code. They also dispute reporting that CVE-2024-22024 (8.3. high, disclosed 12 February by Ivanti) was being exploited after disclosure. "It is unfortunate that media reports continue to cover statements and unverified numbers from third parties that are incorrect or inflated." Ivanti officially responds to the accusations that they didn't credit watchTowr for reporting CVE-2024-22024. This reads like damage control for Ivanti's Public Relations.
🔗 https://www.ivanti.com/blog/key-faqs-related-to-ivanti-connect-secure-policy-secure-and-zta-gateway-vulnerabilities

#Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_21893 #CVE_2024_22024

They also dispute reporting that CVE-2024-22024 (8.3. high, disclosed 12 February by Ivanti) was being exploited after disclosure. "It is unfortunate that media reports continue to cover statements and unverified numbers from third parties that are incorrect or inflated." Ivanti officially responds to the accusations that they didn't credit watchTowr for reporting CVE-2024-22024. This reads like damage control for Ivanti's Public Relations.
🔗 https://www.ivanti.com/blog/key-faqs-related-to-ivanti-connect-secure-policy-secure-and-zta-gateway-vulnerabilities

account.note:
>> INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY RESEARCH LABS ⚡🔍🛡️

KR. Laboratories (kr-labs.com.ua) — це об'єднання IT-професіоналів, які досліджують та популяризують інформаційні технології в Україні.

На цьому сервері Mastodon ми:
├─ Публікуємо свої думки та ідеї, авторські колонки, нотатки, записки, дослідження, розслідування, опитування на різні теми, що стосуються технологій, і не тільки.
├─ Ділимося громадянською позицією, новинами, аналітикою та експертною думкою щодо подій в Україні (та за її межами). Факти, інсайди, ремарки.

Теми:

- Інфо-/кібербезпека
- Операційна безпека
- Національна безпека
- Юридична безпека
- Економічна безпека

posts.content:
Невеличкий PDF-звіт від компанії Hive Pro, який проливає світло на атаку на сервери компанії Ivanti.

https://www.hivepro.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/Ivanti-Addresses-Zero-Day-Vulnerability-Exploited-in-Attacks_TA2024042.pdf

Ivanti — це американська IT-компанія з Юти, яка розробляє програмні рішення з кібербезпеки, для управління ІТ-послугами та активами.

В Лютому 2024 були оприлюднені дві критичні вразливості CVE-2024-21893 і CVE-2024-21888. Невдовзі стало відомо, що хакери провели SSRF-атаку на сервери Ivanti.

Зловмисники знайшли діру на боці сервера, а саме в його компоненті SAML, який заснований на протоколі XML і відповідає за обмін ідентифікаторами автентифікації та авторизації.

Хакери скористались недостатньою валідацією вхідних даних і провели експлойт.

Успішна експлуатація цієї діри привела до встановлення бекдора DSLog, який дозволяє зловмисникам віддалено виконувати команди від імені root на зламаних серверах Ivanti.

Якщо підсумувати, то хакери просто відправляли шкідливі запити (malicious requests), які обманом змусили сервер надсилати їх до своїх внутрішніх ресурсів (без перевірки) й отримати таким чином доступ до сенситивних, конфіденційних даних. Все по класиці.

Важливо відзначити, що ця вразливість сьогодні не рідкість - SSRF набирає потужних обертів і експлуатується повсюдно. На сьогодні чимало веб-додатків і хмарних платформ є вразливими до SSRF (Server-Side Request Forgery).

CVE-2024-21893を利用して、Ivanti Connect Secureの/dev/loop9のデータを取得。EMBAでそれを解析した結果、OSがCentOS 6.4ベース、各パッケージが古いことを確認

また、Ivantiが提供している“Integrity Checking Tool” (ICT)が/data, /etc, /tmp, /var などをスキャンしていないことを確認したという。攻撃者がIvanti Connect Secureを侵害して、これらのディレクトリに攻撃の痕跡を保存した場合、ICTによる整合性チェックを回避できてしまう

posts.content: Analyst comment: It's a little concerning how there's no reporting of active exploitation of CVE-2024-23897 (7.5 high, disclosed 24 January 2024 by Jenkins) an arbitrary file read vulnerability leading to remote code execution. It already has multiple proofs of concept. And yet the only report was a single exploitation in a honeypot capture by a university graduate student, which everyone repeated ad nauseam: https://infosec.exchange/@simontsui/111835020715820485

CVE-2024-23897.description:
Jenkins has a built-in command line interface (CLI) to access Jenkins from a script or shell environment.

Jenkins uses the args4j library to parse command arguments and options on the Jenkins controller when processing CLI commands. This command parser has a feature that replaces an @ character followed by a file path in an argument with the file’s contents (expandAtFiles). This feature is enabled by default and Jenkins 2.441 and earlier, LTS 2.426.2 and earlier does not disable it.

This allows attackers to read arbitrary files on the Jenkins controller file system using the default character encoding of the Jenkins controller process.

* Attackers with Overall/Read permission can read entire files.

* Attackers without Overall/Read permission can read the first few lines of files. The number of lines that can be read depends on available CLI commands. As of publication of this advisory, the Jenkins security team has found ways to read the first three lines of files in recent releases of Jenkins without having any plugins installed, and has not identified any plugins that would increase this line count.

Binary files containing cryptographic keys used for various Jenkins features can also be read, with some limitations (see note on binary files below). As of publication, the Jenkins security team has confirmed the following possible attacks in addition to reading contents of all files with a known file path. All of them leverage attackers' ability to obtain cryptographic keys from binary files, and are therefore only applicable to instances where that is feasible.

CVE-2023-52472.description:
In the Linux kernel, the following vulnerability has been resolved:

crypto: rsa - add a check for allocation failure

Static checkers insist that the mpi_alloc() allocation can fail so add
a check to prevent a NULL dereference.  Small allocations like this
can't actually fail in current kernels, but adding a check is very
simple and makes the static checkers happy.

posts.content:
With respect to the dns bind flaw CVE-2023-50387

“With these changes, a DNSSEC validation attack which bypasses all other limits will be able to consume no more than approximately 1/2 of CPU capacity on the affected machine, leaving the other half for normal processing.”

Like… I guess this is better than the attacker using all of the CPU…

Looks like @sans_isc picked up on an exploit for KeyTrap - I haven't tested it yet, and it is explicitly documented as being defanged, but looks legit on the surface:

https://github.com/knqyf263/CVE-2023-50387

#keytrap #nsec3 #CVE202350387 #CVE_2023_50387

CVE-2023-50387.description: Certain DNSSEC aspects of the DNS protocol (in RFC 4035 and related RFCs) allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (CPU consumption) via one or more DNSSEC responses when there is a zone with many DNSKEY and RRSIG records, aka the "KeyTrap" issue. The protocol specification implies that an algorithm must evaluate all combinations of DNSKEY and RRSIG records.

account.note: Current open-source cyber threat intelligence, critical vulnerabilities, zero-days, proofs of concept, cybercrime/cyberespionage, threat actors/APTs, IOCs, and other cybersecurity and intelligence news.

posts.content:
MSRC (Microsoft) released 11 Chromium-related security advisories. The ones not already included in Google's original post are as follows:

  • CVE-2024-21423 (4.8 medium) Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) Information Disclosure Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-26188 (4.3 medium) Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) Spoofing Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-26192 (8.2 high) Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) Information Disclosure Vulnerability

The Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) section of each vulnerability explains a lot more than Google normally would. Also provides a CVSSv3 score. These are noted as Not Publicly Disclosed, Not Exploited, and Exploitation Less Likely (CVE-2024-26192 is missing an exploitability assessment).

#Microsoft #MSRC #securityadvisory #vulnerability #Chrome #Chromium

posts.content:
A Russo-Belarusian cyber-espionage group tracked as TAG-70 has targeted more than 80 organizations in a campaign that took place last year between October and December.

Notable targets included the Embassy of Iran in Moscow, the Embassy of Iran in the Netherlands, and the Embassy of Georgia in Sweden.

According to Recorded Future, the group used multiple XSS vulnerabilities in Roundcube to gain access to victims' inboxes (likely CVE-2020-35730 and CVE-2023-43770).

https://www.recordedfuture.com/russia-aligned-tag-70-targets-european-government-and-military-mail

account.note: Current open-source cyber threat intelligence, critical vulnerabilities, zero-days, proofs of concept, cybercrime/cyberespionage, threat actors/APTs, IOCs, and other cybersecurity and intelligence news.

posts.content:
Recorded Future identified TAG-70, a Belarus and Russia-aligned threat actor, conducting cyberespionage against government, military, and national infrastructure entities in Europe and Central Asia since at least December 2020. Its latest campaign ran between October and December 2023, exploiting CVE-2023-5631 cross-site scripting (XSS) in Roundcube webmail servers. Targeting of over 80 organizations, primarily in Georgia, Poland, and Ukraine. This activity is reminiscent of other Russian-aligned threat groups such as BlueDelta (APT28) and Sandworm, which have targeted email solutions (including Roundcube) in previous campaigns. 15 page report with IOC provided.
🔗 https://www.recordedfuture.com/russia-aligned-tag-70-targets-european-government-and-military-mail

#Russia #TAG70 #threatintel #cyberespionage #Belarus #Ukraine #Georgia #Poland #APT28 #BlueDelta #Sandworm #cybersecurity

CVE-2023-5631.description:
Roundcube before 1.4.15, 1.5.x before 1.5.5, and 1.6.x before 1.6.4 allows stored XSS via an HTML e-mail message with a crafted SVG document because of program/lib/Roundcube/rcube_washtml.php behavior. This could allow a remote attacker

to load arbitrary JavaScript code.

posts.content:
VulnCheck's Jacob Baines has discovered that a recent vulnerability disclosed in Zyxel firewalls by SSD researchers is actually an older bug tracked as CVE-2023-33012.

"The associated disclosure did not mention any caveats to exploitation, but it turns out only an uncommon configuration is affected. There are currently about 600 internet-facing Zyxel firewalls vulnerable to this issue (out of ~26,000)."

There is no evidence of exploitation in the wild.

https://vulncheck.com/blog/zyxel-cve-2023-33012

CVE-2021-44228.description:
# Summary

Log4j versions prior to 2.16.0 are subject to a remote code execution vulnerability via the ldap JNDI parser.
As per [Apache's Log4j security guide](https://logging.apache.org/log4j/2.x/security.html): Apache Log4j2 <=2.14.1 JNDI features used in configuration, log messages, and parameters do not protect against attacker controlled LDAP and other JNDI related endpoints. An attacker who can control log messages or log message parameters can execute arbitrary code loaded from LDAP servers when message lookup substitution is enabled. From log4j 2.16.0, this behavior has been disabled by default.

Log4j version 2.15.0 contained an earlier fix for the vulnerability, but that patch did not disable attacker-controlled JNDI lookups in all situations. For more information, see the `Updated advice for version 2.16.0` section of this advisory.

# Impact

Logging untrusted or user controlled data with a vulnerable version of Log4J may result in Remote Code Execution (RCE) against your application. This includes untrusted data included in logged errors such as exception traces, authentication failures, and other unexpected vectors of user controlled input. 

# Affected versions

Any Log4J version prior to v2.15.0 is affected to this specific issue.

The v1 branch of Log4J which is considered End Of Life (EOL) is vulnerable to other RCE vectors so the recommendation is to still update to 2.16.0 where possible.

## Security releases
Additional backports of this fix have been made available in versions 2.3.1, 2.12.2, and 2.12.3

## Affected packages
Only the `org.apache.logging.log4j:log4j-core` package is directly affected by this vulnerability. The `org.apache.logging.log4j:log4j-api` should be kept at the same version as the `org.apache.logging.log4j:log4j-core` package to ensure compatability if in use.

# Remediation Advice

## Updated advice for version 2.16.0

The Apache Logging Services team provided updated mitigation advice upon the release of version 2.16.0, which [disables JNDI by default and completely removes support for message lookups](https://logging.apache.org/log4j/2.x/changes-report.html#a2.16.0).
Even in version 2.15.0, lookups used in layouts to provide specific pieces of context information will still recursively resolve, possibly triggering JNDI lookups. This problem is being tracked as [CVE-2021-45046](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-45046). More information is available on the [GitHub Security Advisory for CVE-2021-45046](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-7rjr-3q55-vv33).

Users who want to avoid attacker-controlled JNDI lookups but cannot upgrade to 2.16.0 must [ensure that no such lookups resolve to attacker-provided data and ensure that the the JndiLookup class is not loaded](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LOG4J2-3221).

Please note that Log4J v1 is End Of Life (EOL) and will not receive patches for this issue. Log4J v1 is also vulnerable to other RCE vectors and we recommend you migrate to Log4J 2.16.0 where possible.

CVE-2023-52160.description: The implementation of PEAP in wpa_supplicant through 2.10 allows authentication bypass. For a successful attack, wpa_supplicant must be configured to not verify the network's TLS certificate during Phase 1 authentication, and an eap_peap_decrypt vulnerability can then be abused to skip Phase 2 authentication. The attack vector is sending an EAP-TLV Success packet instead of starting Phase 2. This allows an adversary to impersonate Enterprise Wi-Fi networks.

posts.content: anecdotal, but a few months ago someone filed a bogus CVE against tmux (CVE-2022-47016), I was notified via the Debian security team. other distros started shipping a "fix" which actually turned a NULL-deref into a call to fatal(), i.e. no functional change. I challenged the CVE via some web form, and a few hours later someone wrote back saying that the CVE had been rejected. so the system worked for me, at least…

CVE-2022-47016.description: A null pointer dereference issue was discovered in function window_pane_set_event in window.c in tmux 3.0 thru 3.3 allows attackers to cause denial of service or other unspecified impacts.

posts.content:
Si vous administrez un serveur de messagerie Exchange on-prem, c'est le moment de le mettre à jour. 🩹​

Une faille récemment découverte, identifiée sous le nom de CVE-2024-21410, affecte environ 97’000 serveurs Exchange mondialement, avec 2’119 serveurs vulnérables identifiés en Suisse selon la fondation Shadowserver. Cette vulnérabilité permet, par exemple, des attaques de relais NTLM, mettant en péril les informations d'identification NTLM qui peuvent être exploitées pour obtenir des privilèges non autorisés. Microsoft recommande d'appliquer la mise à jour Cumulative Update 14 (CU14) pour Exchange Server 2019 pour sécuriser les systèmes contre cette menace.
👇​
https://www.ictjournal.ch/news/2024-02-20/plus-de-2000-serveurs-exchange-suisses-vulnerables-a-une-faille

[Advisory Microsoft]
👇​
https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/en-US/advisory/CVE-2024-21410

[Guide Microsoft]
👇​
https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/exchange-team-blog/released-2024-h1-cumulative-update-for-exchange-server/ba-p/4047506

[Détection Shadowserver]

posts.content:
CISA adds two to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog, based on evidence of active exploitation:

  • CVE-2020-3259 (7.5 high, disclosed 06 May 2020 by Cisco) Cisco ASA and FTD Information Disclosure Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-21410 (9.8 critical, disclosed 13 February 2024 by Microsoft, updated 14 Feb as exploited zero-day) Microsoft Exchange Server Privilege Escalation Vulnerability

🔗 https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/02/15/cisa-adds-two-known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog

#CISA #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #KEV #eitw #activeexploitation #CVE_2020_3259 #CVE_2024_21410 #Microsoft #vulnerability #Cisco #Firepower #zeroday

CVE-2020-3259.description: A vulnerability in the web services interface of Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Software and Cisco Firepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to retrieve memory contents on an affected device, which could lead to the disclosure of confidential information. The vulnerability is due to a buffer tracking issue when the software parses invalid URLs that are requested from the web services interface. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted GET request to the web services interface. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to retrieve memory contents, which could lead to the disclosure of confidential information. Note: This vulnerability affects only specific AnyConnect and WebVPN configurations. For more information, see the Vulnerable Products section.

posts.content:
Cisco published a security advisory: CVE-2024-20325 (5.1 medium) Cisco Unified Intelligence Center Insufficient Access Control Vulnerability. Not exploited.

A vulnerability in the Live Data server of Cisco Unified Intelligence Center could allow an unauthenticated, local attacker to read and modify data in a repository that belongs to an internal service on an affected device. This vulnerability is due to insufficient access control implementations on cluster configuration CLI requests. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a cluster configuration CLI request to specific directories on an affected device. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to read and modify data that is handled by an internal service on the affected device.

🔗 https://sec.cloudapps.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-cuic-access-control-jJsZQMjj

#Cisco #CVE_2024_20325 #CiscoUnifiedIntelligenceCenter #accesscontrol #vulnerability

posts.content:
Aqua reports that the Lucifer DDoS botnet exploits Apache Hadoop and Apache Druid vulnerabilities CVE-2021-25646 and existing misconfigurations to transform vulnerable Linux systems into Monero cryptomining bots. Aqua illustrates the various phases of the campaign, and highlight the differences observed throughout its operation. IOC provided.

posts.content:
Aqua reports that the Lucifer DDoS botnet exploits Apache Hadoop and Apache Druid vulnerabilities CVE-2021-25646 and existing misconfigurations to transform vulnerable Linux systems into Monero cryptomining bots. Aqua illustrates the various phases of the campaign, and highlight the differences observed throughout its operation. IOC provided.
🔗 https://www.aquasec.com/blog/lucifer-ddos-botnet-malware-is-targeting-apache-big-data-stack/

#cybercrime #threatintel #Apache #Hadoop #ApacheDruid #Monero #cryptomining #IOC #CVE_2021_25646 #eitw #activeexploitation

CVE-2021-25646.description: Apache Druid includes the ability to execute user-provided JavaScript code embedded in various types of requests. This functionality is intended for use in high-trust environments, and is disabled by default. However, in Druid 0.20.0 and earlier, it is possible for an authenticated user to send a specially-crafted request that forces Druid to run user-provided JavaScript code for that request, regardless of server configuration. This can be leveraged to execute code on the target machine with the privileges of the Druid server process.

CVE-2024-26581.description:
netfilter: nft_set_rbtree: skip end interval element from gc

rbtree lazy gc on insert might collect an end interval element that has
been just added in this transactions, skip end interval elements that
are not yet active.

posts.content:
The #Linux #kernel CVE team released their first two CVEs:

* CVE-2023-52433: netfilter: nft_set_rbtree: skip sync GC for new elements in this transaction
https://lore.kernel.org/linux-cve-announce/2024022058-outsell-equator-e1c5@gregkh/

* CVE-2024-26581: netfilter: nft_set_rbtree: skip end interval element from gc

For more details on the new #LinuxKernel CVE process, see https://docs.kernel.org/process/cve.html (recently added by https://git.kernel.org/torvalds/c/5928d411557ec5d53832cdd39fc443704a3e5b77 )

Screenshot from https://lore.kernel.org/linux-cve-announce/

CVE-2023-52433.description:
In the Linux kernel, the following vulnerability has been resolved:

netfilter: nft_set_rbtree: skip sync GC for new elements in this transaction

New elements in this transaction might expired before such transaction
ends. Skip sync GC for such elements otherwise commit path might walk
over an already released object. Once transaction is finished, async GC
will collect such expired element.

posts.content:
Hello #MITRE, (regarding CVE-2023-52071)

Well, first I of course think that the "burden of proof" would be on the person that insists that there is a problem. The one saying that this is a #CVE should provide the necessary details to explain "beyond reasonable doubt" that the identified problem is a vulnerability. There are no such details or explanations provided in the existing CVE. There is nothing there that identifies a vulnerability.

CVE-2023-1389.description: TP-Link Archer AX21 (AX1800) firmware versions before 1.1.4 Build 20230219 contained a command injection vulnerability in the country form of the /cgi-bin/luci;stok=/locale endpoint on the web management interface. Specifically, the country parameter of the write operation was not sanitized before being used in a call to popen(), allowing an unauthenticated attacker to inject commands, which would be run as root, with a simple POST request.

posts.content:
@patrickcmiller : Germany's eID system vulnerable to AitM (*) attacks, leading to possible (hard to dispute) impersonation / identity fraud

(*) Attacker in the Middle

Note that this vulnerablity may affect other or all "electronic passports".

The German site Heise.de (well known in western Europe, publisher of popular paper IT magazines such as c't and iX) reports [1] that a researcher was able to attack the German "eID", an electronic passport using a malicious smartphone app.

BSI, Germany's Federal Office for Information Security [2], acknowledges the vulnerability (CVE-2024-23674) but says [3] that there is no fix (I fully agree, device compromise means game over - even if the secrets themselves are safely stored in the passport itself, in a "secure hardware enclave" in a smartphone, or in a TPM in a PC).

The researcher, "CtrlAlt", published an extensive English write-up (plus PDF) at:

[0] https://ctrlalt.medium.com/space-attack-spoofing-eids-password-authenticated-connection-establishment-11561e5657b1

This risk will be exacerbated for European citizens once they can download iOS/iPadOS apps from alternative "app stores" (the EU forces Apple to allow this).

I'd like to point out that eID apps are typically VULNERABLE TO PHISHING AS WELL (not requiring device compromise and/or malicious apps): a fake (AitM) website may ask a person to authenticate using their electronic passport, and forward such credentials to another website, impersonating the real person.

Furthermore, in December BSI together with their French collegues ANSSI published "Remote Identity Proofing" [4], assessing the risks of "VideoIdent" - to my surprise not mentioning AitM's at all. Not to mention the rapidly increasing risk from AI (such as OpenAI's Sora, which generates artificial videos).

In my opinion some things cannot be digitalized reliably without significantly increasing risks - in particular for vulnerable people (those with limited cybersecurity awareness and/or those using old, no longer supported, hardware).

Authentication, involving significant risks (for the person authenticating), therefore requiring maximum reliability, can only be achieved IN A LIVE SETTING by letting trustworthy verifiers thoroughly check hard-to-duplicate passports for falsifications and/or manipulations, and asserting that the person matches their passport-photo (plus any other physically identifying attributes).

Yes, this is more expensive, time-consuming and inconvenient, but in my opinion inevitable if risks are to be kept low.

[1] (German) https://www.heise.de/news/AusweisApp-Kritische-Schwachstelle-erlaubt-Uebernahme-fremder-Identitaeten-9630452.html

[2] https://bsi.bund.de/EN/

[3] (German) https://www.bsi.bund.de/DE/Service-Navi/Presse/Pressemitteilungen/Presse2024/240216_Hinweis-auf-eID-Schwachstelle.html

[4] https://www.bsi.bund.de/SharedDocs/Downloads/EN/BSI/Publications/ANSSI-BSI-joint-releases/ANSSI-BSI_joint-release_2023.html

P.S. A personal thank you for keeping many followers informed on current security risks!

#eID #authentication #impersonation #IdentityFraud #idfraud #passport #ElectronicPassport #MaliciousApps #AitM #MitM #sideloading #BSI #ANSSI #EU

posts.content:
@patrickcmiller : Germany's eID system vulnerable to AitM (*) attacks, leading to possible (hard to dispute) impersonation / identity fraud

(*) Attacker in the Middle

Note that this vulnerablity may affect other or all "electronic passports".

The German site Heise.de (well known in western Europe, publisher of popular paper IT magazines such as c't and iX) reports [1] that a researcher was able to attack the German "eID", an electronic passport using a malicious smartphone app.

BSI, Germany's Federal Office for Information Security [2], acknowledges the vulnerability (CVE-2024-23674) but says [3] that there is no fix (I fully agree, device compromise means game over - even if the secrets themselves are safely stored in the passport itself, in a "secure hardware enclave" in a smartphone, or in a TPM in a PC).

The researcher, "CtrlAlt", published an extensive English write-up (plus PDF) at:

[0] https://ctrlalt.medium.com/space-attack-spoofing-eids-password-authenticated-connection-establishment-11561e5657b1

This risk will be exacerbated for European citizens once they can download iOS/iPadOS apps from alternative "app stores" (the EU forces Apple to allow this).

I'd like to point out that eID apps are typically VULNERABLE TO PHISHING AS WELL (not requiring device compromise and/or malicious apps): a fake (AitM) website may ask a person to authenticate using their electronic passport, and forward such credentials to another website, impersonating the real person.

Furthermore, in December BSI together with their French collegues ANSSI published "Remote Identity Proofing" [4], assessing the risks of "VideoIdent" - to my surprise not mentioning AitM's at all. Not to mention the rapidly increasing risk from AI (such as OpenAI's Sora, which generates artificial videos).

In my opinion some things cannot be digitalized reliably without significantly increasing risks - in particular for vulnerable people (those with limited cybersecurity awareness and/or those using old, no longer supported, hardware).

Authentication, involving significant risks (for the person authenticating), therefore requiring maximum reliability, can only be achieved IN A LIVE SETTING by letting trustworthy verifiers thoroughly check hard-to-duplicate passports for falsifications and/or manipulations, and asserting that the person matches their passport-photo (plus any other physically identifying attributes).

Yes, this is more expensive, time-consuming and inconvenient, but in my opinion inevitable if risks are to be kept low.

[1] (German) https://www.heise.de/news/AusweisApp-Kritische-Schwachstelle-erlaubt-Uebernahme-fremder-Identitaeten-9630452.html

[2] https://bsi.bund.de/EN/

[3] (German) https://www.bsi.bund.de/DE/Service-Navi/Presse/Pressemitteilungen/Presse2024/240216_Hinweis-auf-eID-Schwachstelle.html

[4] https://www.bsi.bund.de/SharedDocs/Downloads/EN/BSI/Publications/ANSSI-BSI-joint-releases/ANSSI-BSI_joint-release_2023.html

P.S. A personal thank you for keeping many followers informed on current security risks!

#eID #authentication #impersonation #IdentityFraud #idfraud #passport #ElectronicPassport #MaliciousApps #AitM #MitM #sideloading #BSI #ANSSI #EU

CVE-2024-23674.description: The Online-Ausweis-Funktion eID scheme in the German National Identity card through 2024-02-15 allows authentication bypass by spoofing. A man-in-the-middle attacker can assume a victim's identify for access to government, medical, and financial resources, and can also extract personal data from the card, aka the "sPACE (Spoofing Password Authenticated Connection Establishment)" issue. This occurs because of a combination of factors, such as insecure PIN entry (for basic readers) and eid:// deeplinking. The victim must be using a modified eID kernel, which may occur if the victim is tricked into installing a fake version of an official app. NOTE: the BSI position is "ensuring a secure operational environment at the client side is an obligation of the ID card owner."

posts.content:
Whilst I'm talking about Mastodon, as in the service itself...

Esther takes care of the platform side of things. Usually when an update is released we are on the latest version almost immediately (thanks, Esther :Blobhaj_Ani_Hearts:​)

This means I was only vaguely aware of the security vulnerabilities that needed to be patched, with two (?) separate updates.

I did not, however, know the severity of them until I read this summary by the person who discovered them. Thanks @arcanicanis for finding these, reporting them responsibly, and writing a summary of events.

https://arcanican.is/excerpts/cve-2024-23832/discovery.htm

If you are not on the latest version, these vulnerabilities are public and running an outdated version of mastodon (and some other unnamed activitypub instance softwares) means you are running with severe security issues.

posts.content:
Wowzers, that Mastodon CVE recently was quite something:

• You can inject a post that is attributed to any remote user
• You can overwrite the server's copy of any remote user
• You can rekey the server's copy of any remote user, by just listing another key

The full technical write up is worth a read: https://arcanican.is/excerpts/cve-2024-23832/discovery.htm

posts.content:
@PC_Fluesterer 1. Klar, ist nicht Teil von dem Linux Kernel, sogar nicht von GNU/Linux. Jetzt können wir natürlich einen Linux-Kernel mit lediglich GNU Tools mit einem gesamten Windows-Desktop vergleichen. Ich hoffe die Absurdität dieses Vergleiches ist auch dir bekannt. Ghostscript gehört genauso zu einem Linux-Desktop wie Wordpad.exe zu einem Windows-System gehört, und das obwohl *überraschung* Wordpad.exe weder zum NT-Kernel gehört noch zu den CMD Services (als äquivalent zu GNU coreutils). Im Übrigen ist auf dem Blog genau in dem Abschnitt eine Sicherheitslücke verlinkt, die ein Problem in MS Office ausnutzt mit "zwei, drei einfache Klicks". Meines Wissens ist MS Office nicht mal in der Standardinstallation von Windows enthalten.

Meine Bitte daher: Nicht Apfel mit Birnen vergleichen. Wenn du MS Office (nicht vorinstalliert) anbringst, dann darf ich doch *hoffentlich* den Linux Dateimanager (bei jedem Linux mit GUI vorinstalliert) anbringen. Oder geht es dir gar nicht um Fakten?

2. Ja, genauso wie bei Windows, wenn ich einen separaten Account mache. Geht seit Win XP. Oder vergleichen wir jetzt Windows XP mit dem Linux 2.6.32 von damals? Zeitreise kann ich auch.

Zu CVE-2022-47939: Sehr viele Angriffe auf Windows Server laufen via offenes SMB ab. Wie gesagt, ich wäre für Fair Play

Was hast du sonst zu bieten?

posts.content:
@PC_Fluesterer (3) Ja, solche Ransomware gab es kaum, da Grund (1) zieht: Linux-Desktops(!) sind kaum verbreitet und solche Malware ist v.A. für Angriffe auf Desktops relevant. Denn Sicherheitslücken die so simpel ausgenutzt werden könnten gab es alle mal:

Letztes Jahr CVE-2023-36664 in ghostscript (auch installierbar unter Windows aber per default v.A. auf Linux-Systemen). Hier waren bösartige PDFs das Problem, eine Preview im File Manager reicht aus :)

Davor sogar im Kernel mit CVE-2022-47939 im kSMB zum Zugriff auf SMB Dienste.

Oder der gnome-tracker (und analoge Services auf anderen DEs).

Gibt noch deutlich mehr, aber CVE Anzahlen zu vergleichen ist eh Murks. Der Punkt ist: Es gibt Sicherheitslücken die genauso trivial auszunutzen waren/sind wie auf Windows Systemen. Entsprechende Ransomware wird aber selten gebaut.

(4) Und hui, ja doch, es gibt genau solche Mist auch auf Linux. Nicht konkret ADS aber einiges im sysfs und setuid sind so richtig kaputt. Hinreichend viel ist da broken by design.

posts.content:
@PC_Fluesterer 1. Klar, ist nicht Teil von dem Linux Kernel, sogar nicht von GNU/Linux. Jetzt können wir natürlich einen Linux-Kernel mit lediglich GNU Tools mit einem gesamten Windows-Desktop vergleichen. Ich hoffe die Absurdität dieses Vergleiches ist auch dir bekannt. Ghostscript gehört genauso zu einem Linux-Desktop wie Wordpad.exe zu einem Windows-System gehört, und das obwohl *überraschung* Wordpad.exe weder zum NT-Kernel gehört noch zu den CMD Services (als äquivalent zu GNU coreutils). Im Übrigen ist auf dem Blog genau in dem Abschnitt eine Sicherheitslücke verlinkt, die ein Problem in MS Office ausnutzt mit "zwei, drei einfache Klicks". Meines Wissens ist MS Office nicht mal in der Standardinstallation von Windows enthalten.

Meine Bitte daher: Nicht Apfel mit Birnen vergleichen. Wenn du MS Office (nicht vorinstalliert) anbringst, dann darf ich doch *hoffentlich* den Linux Dateimanager (bei jedem Linux mit GUI vorinstalliert) anbringen. Oder geht es dir gar nicht um Fakten?

2. Ja, genauso wie bei Windows, wenn ich einen separaten Account mache. Geht seit Win XP. Oder vergleichen wir jetzt Windows XP mit dem Linux 2.6.32 von damals? Zeitreise kann ich auch.

Zu CVE-2022-47939: Sehr viele Angriffe auf Windows Server laufen via offenes SMB ab. Wie gesagt, ich wäre für Fair Play

Was hast du sonst zu bieten?

2024年02月10日収録の #セキュリティのアレ https://twitter.com/ntsuji/status/1756999767727734918

* Outlookの情報漏洩の脆弱性:CVE-2023-35636

2ヶ月ぶりに聴きましたが、どの話題も面白かったです。個人的にはCVE-2023-35636の話が一番楽しかった

「なんでCVE-2023-35636を取り上げるか分からない」とコメントされていましたが、むしろ取り上げてもらって嬉しい脆弱性でした。緊急性の高い脆弱性の場合、ニュースメディアなどで十分に知る機会があります。一方、Outlookの脆弱性:CVE-2023-35636は意識的に情報を読まないと知れない気がします。こういった悪用が限定される脆弱性を取り上げた場合、その人の興味や好みが反映される気がして、聴いていて楽しいです

posts.content:
Nginx core developer quits project in security dispute, starts “freenginx” fork

Disagreement over security disclosures and bug-fixing priorities led to split.

US networking vendor F5 acquired Russian web server Nginx for $670 million in 2019.

Some of F5's decisions, such as the recent disclosure of CVE-2024-24989, have upset the core developer, who vocally disagreed with this disclosure.

https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2024/02/nginx-key-developer-starts-a-freenginx-fork-after-dispute-with-parent-firm/

CVE-2024-24989.description:
When NGINX Plus or NGINX OSS are configured to use the HTTP/3 QUIC module, undisclosed requests can cause NGINX worker processes to terminate.

Note: The HTTP/3 QUIC module is not enabled by default and is considered experimental. For more information, refer to  Support for QUIC and HTTP/3 https://nginx.org/en/docs/quic.html .



NOTE: Software versions which have reached End of Technical Support (EoTS) are not evaluated

account.note: Current open-source cyber threat intelligence, critical vulnerabilities, zero-days, proofs of concept, cybercrime/cyberespionage, threat actors/APTs, IOCs, and other cybersecurity and intelligence news.

posts.content:
Rapid7 provides a case study on two publicly-facing Atlassian Confluence servers that were the source of multiple malware executions. They determined exploitation of CVE-2023-22527 (CVSSv3: 9.8 critical, disclosed 16 January 204) which led to cryptomining software and a Sliver C2 payload. Rapid7 provided post-exploitation activity (observed attacker behavior), MITRE ATT&CK TTPs, and IOC.
🔗 https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2024/02/15/rce-to-sliver-ir-tales-from-the-field/

#Rapid7 #DFIR #threatintel #IOC #Sliver #Atlassian #Confluence #CVE_2023_22527

CVE-2023-22527.description:
A template injection vulnerability on older versions of Confluence Data Center and Server allows an unauthenticated attacker to achieve RCE on an affected instance. Customers using an affected version must take immediate action.

Most recent supported versions of Confluence Data Center and Server are not affected by this vulnerability as it was ultimately mitigated during regular version updates. However, Atlassian recommends that customers take care to install the latest version to protect their instances from non-critical vulnerabilities outlined in Atlassian’s January Security Bulletin.
